lines: PRESIDENT:  Good morning.  We are meeting today to commence
the hearing in ICC case number 27146/HTG, Primetals
Technologies India Pte Ltd and Steel Authority
India Ltd, Pomini Long Rolling Mills SRL and Shriram
EPC Ltd.
On behalf of the tribunal, I would like to welcome
the parties to the hearing.
Today we are starting with the parties' opening
presentations.  But before we do so, perhaps I could
just ask each of the parties to introduce their teams,
and then if there are any housekeeping matters, we can
go on to address them.
So perhaps starting with the claimant, Mr Markanda.
(Introductions were made)
PRESIDENT:  Thank you very much.
I have assumed that all of the attendees are on the
hearing attendee list, but of course if there's anybody
else that is not on the list who the parties wish to
add, they simply need to let us know.
I also note the presence of at least one of the
factual witnesses.
The procedural order had provided that factual
witnesses would not attend the hearing until they gave
evidence, but of course if no party objects to the
attendance of factual witnesses for the openings, then
we can proceed on that basis.
So could I ask the parties if there is an objection?
MS ARORA:  Yes, because we haven't brought our factual
witnesses for the same reason.  So I think it's only
fair that all factual witnesses may abstain till such
time as they have given their evidence.
PRESIDENT:  Thank you, Ms Arora.
MR ANCHALIA:  Honourable President, I do have a factual
witness, and I have no objection in him going out and
joining once his deposition is over.
PRESIDENT:  It's not because he's not welcome, Mr Anchalia.
MR ANCHALIA:  I do understand.  Absolutely no issues, madam.
PRESIDENT:  Thank you.  Perhaps we could arrange for him to
be released for today.
MR ANCHALIA:  While introducing, I did mention that I have
a factual witness with me, madam.
PRESIDENT:  Yes.  I assume there are no other factual
witnesses that are present.  Of course, within
procedural order number 8, experts may attend the
hearing, but factual witnesses are in a different
category.
Before we move on to the openings, are there any
other housekeeping matters that the parties wish to
raise at this stage?
MS ARORA:  We have a very small thing.  During the course of
these submissions, if any new legal submission or
judgments emerge, can we please tender that in?  It's
a clarity that we would like to have.
Nothing which would be anything which relates to an
evidence or factual material, but only maybe in that
case, law or something that emerges, apropos to the
arguments or submissions made by the parties, if that
needs to be countered.  That would be one.
I would also like to clarify.  I didn't catch it.
The expert witnesses, can they stay in?  Because we
would need from them the instructions from time to time,
since we are not experts ourselves.  So some inputs
could be required.  But that's subject to what the
tribunal has to say.
PRESIDENT:  I believe procedural order number 8 stipulated
that expert witnesses could be present throughout the
hearing.  I think that's the basis on which we've been
proceeding, so that does provide that clarification.
So far as concerns the suggestion that new legal
submissions or judgments could be tendered during the
hearing, could I hear if any of the other parties have
any objections to that proposal?
MR MARKANDA:  We have no objection.
MR ANCHALIA:  I simply would submit that the honourable
tribunal has already given another opportunity to bring
on record additional legal authorities and all.  After
giving the skeleton arguments, whatever legal
authorities are to be brought in, is to be brought in
during that opportunity window, rather than bringing it
here and putting us to absolute surprise.
PRESIDENT:  Perhaps we could -- Mr Anchalia, as well the
procedural order does specify that there is scope for
putting in legal authorities before the post-hearing
written submissions as well.  So shall we see how we go,
in terms of new legal authorities?
If there is a particular objection, if one is
tendered and there is a particular objection, then
I propose we would deal with that when that arises.
I'm not expecting that there will be hundreds of new
cases that are being handed up, I should hope at this
stage, but we may retain that flexibility, I think,
and see.
MR ANCHALIA:  I shall have no issues, madam, in case they
are given in advance to us also, to consider before
bringing in before the honourable arbitral tribunal.
PRESIDENT:  Certainly each party --
(Technical break)
PRESIDENT:  We'll see how we go with legal authorities.  Of
course, if there is an objection to any specific
authority, the tribunal will deal with that.
Are there any other matters of housekeeping?
MR ANCHALIA:  If I may be permitted to --
PRESIDENT:  Yes, Mr Anchalia.
MR ANCHALIA:  Just one clarification, nobody is prevented
from arguing on any legal point, it is always allowed as
law, a provision of law.  Nobody is permitted not to --
the thing.  If there is any legal authorities being
brought on, what I'm asking, I should be given an
opportunity in advance so that I can also have any
counter legal argument, that's all.  Otherwise no issues
at all, madam.
PRESIDENT:  Perhaps if the other parties know that they wish
to refer to legal authorities already, copies should be
exchanged at the earliest opportunity.  Thank you very
much, Mr Anchalia.
Any other matters of housekeeping?
No?  Thank you, then I shall ask the claimant to
make their opening submissions, for which they have up
to one hour and 45 minutes.  We will take a break at
Opening submissions by MR MARKANDA
MR MARKANDA:  With the kind permission of the honourable
tribunal I'll make my submissions on behalf of the
claimant.  Your Lordships, the parties have already
filed their skeletal submissions, which are on the
record of my Lords, and my Lords will already be having
overview of the entire case about the parties, so I'll
be just presenting an opening submission just general
speaking, because after the evidence I will be going to
detailed issues with the closing submissions.
My Lords, in this case, respondent number 1 was
desirous of setting up a medium structural mill, which
I shall refer to as MSM in my submissions, in Durgapur,
West Bengal.  The bid was issued on 23 October 2007.
Our bid was submitted on 28 February 2008.
"Our" bid means we as a consortium, so there are
three parties in the consortium and I'll come to the
three parties a little later, a little bit afterwards.
Now, my bid is on 28 February 2008 and the letter of
allotment is issued to me on 1 April 2010, which means
about 25 months later.
For this 25 months, they were assessing the bids, so
we have no issues with that as well.
The contract document was executed on 11 May 2010.
In other words, I will just invite the kind
attention of the honourable tribunal to the contract
document which is in bundle {E7}. I just want to
introduce the parties to my Lords.  I'm referring to the
very first page of that.  It's on the screen, my Lords.
So my Lords, it says:
"The contract number ... made on this 11th Day of
May, Two Thousand Ten at Durgapur Steel Plant, Durgapur,
West Bengal India
Between
Steel Authority of India Limited ..."
So, my Lord, that is (inaudible) number 1 before the
honourable tribunal.  Then comes the next:
"And
"Consortium [consisting] of
"... Siemens VAI Metal Technologies SRL ..."
This was a company in Italy.  The next:
"And
"... Siemens VAI Metals Technologies Pvt Ltd ..."
This is the Indian arm, and the third party is
Shriram EPC Ltd.  This is respondent number 3.
During the course of the contract, Siemens was taken
over by Mitsubishi and therefore, the Siemens was
replaced by Primetals, which is a subsidiary of
Mitsubishi.  So this Siemens VAI Technologies SRL became
Primetals Italy and Siemens VAI Metals Technology
Pvt Ltd became Primetals India.
This change was duly recognised by respondent
number 1 through their letter dated 7 May 2015, which is
bundle , page 1. We need not go to that.
So therefore, it was duly recognised that the name
of the parties was changed, and it was -- if my Lords
will focus on the screen:
"... Sirs,
Reference above and consequent upon the transfer of
local MT business of Siemens Limited to VAI Metals
Technologies Private Limited, the name of the
'Contractor Consortium Leader' of subject contract and
subsequent related documents is hereby amended from
M/s VAI ... Technologies Private Limited to
M/s Primetals Technologies India Private Limited.
However, the above acceptance shall not relieve M/s
Primetals Technologies India Private Limited (formerly
M/s Siemens VAI Metals Technologies Private Limited /
M/s Messrs Siemens Limited / M/s VAI Metals Technologies
Private Limited) from any of the duties,
responsibilities and other obligations under the said
contract.
All other terms and conditions of the above cited
contract remain unchanged."
So, my Lords, the party Siemens was replaced by
Primetals.  This is a matter of fact about which again
there is no dispute between the parties.
Now, my Lords, the total time for completion of the
entire project was 28 months, commencing from
11 May 2010.  This included all the civil work, the
foundation work, so from the start till the end.
So as I would be just showing in the PowerPoint
presentation, the entire project consisted of various
responsibilities of different parties.  Some of it was
respondent number 1, some of it was respondent number 3,
some of it was me.  So it was distributed.  We'll just
show it on the screen, my Lords.
It's a matter of record that 28 months, just nothing
happened.  The contract -- and the date actually was
8 September 2012.  So the entire mill should have been
set up by 2012.
Evidently, as per record, it could not be done
within that period, because there were initially delays
in the civil construction thereof.  Those are within the
scope of respondent number 1 inasmuch as they had
changed the civil contractor also because of the delays
being created by him.
Therefore, my Lords, I would just invite the kind
attention of the honourable tribunal to one article of
the contract, which is bundle {E7}, page 5. This is
time for completion.  Article 5, the honourable tribunal
has it on the screen.
"Time for Completion (Reference GCC Clause 8 &
Appendix-2)
Time is an important feature of the Contract.
Completion period shall be considered as date of
Commissioning mentioned in Commissioning Certificate.
The Facilities will be completed in 28 ... months
from the Effective Date of the Contract.  The Facilities
shall be considered as completed on date of
commissioning.  Performance guarantee parameters will be
established by the Contractor within a period of six ...
months from the date of commissioning.
The Contractor shall ..."
That part you can skip.
So the two things which I wanted to highlight were,
number 1, period is 28 months, and that would be the
date mentioned on the commissioning certificate.
Secondly, time is an important feature of the contract.
In other words, what it says is that time is of the
essence of the contract.  So, therefore, the parties are
bound by this time limit of 28 months, though what
happened is different issue altogether.
Now, the work proceeded.  Civil work was delayed.
Therefore my role was to come much later, after
completion of the civil works.
So at this stage, I would request the honourable
tribunal to just have a look at three or four slides of
the PowerPoint presentation and my colleague Maitri will
assist the honourable tribunal in this regard.
Opening submissions by MS SINGH
MS SINGH:  My Lords, if we can see on slide number 2,
please, so this is the entire layout, the map of the
entire mill that stands in front of us, and on the right
if we can see there are five areas with different
colours on it.  So these were the areas which consisted
of the entire process flow of how the mill was supposed
to be set up area by area, and which equipment was to go
where.
The first area included of the cold charge, the
weighing, the reheating furnace and the water descaler.
If I go into the detail of it, please, next slide.
Once we zoom into it, the first two stands where we have
labelling it as "Cold Charging Tables", that is where
the raw billet of steel comes in and it is weighed in
and then it is transported to the reheating furnace.
The reheating furnace was in the scope of the work of
respondent number 1, that is SAIL.
After being heated in the reheating furnace for
about two hours, once the steel billet is hot enough to
be put into another shape, it comes out from the
reheating furnace and directly goes under high pressure
of water for any sort of impurities that are formed at
a very high temperature of heating the steel billet.
After that, we go to the second -- that concludes in
the area 1 of what the process flow of the steel plant
contains.  Going to the next slide, which contains of
area 2, we come now to the roughing train, the crop
shear and the finishing train.
So the roughing train is basically six tanks where
the billet now, which is heated to an adequate
temperature, undergoes the first shaping of whatever
shape the client might want.  It can be circular, it can
be square-shaped, it can be a beam, it can be a channel,
different shapes.  And after that, the ends of the beam,
the elongated beam, are cut off with a crop shear,
because those are not in perfect shape.
After that, it goes to the finishing train, which
consists of 10 stands where, as the name suggests, the
billet is finished into the final shape or the shape or
the size that the client wants.
Going on to the next slide, which is area 3, it
consists of three parts again: the dividing shear, the
cooling bed and the straightening machine.
The first part, the dividing shear, is used to cut
the billets into the commercial lengths, which the
customer wants.  After that it goes -- after it is cut
into desired lengths, which can be short bars or long
bars, it goes to the cooling bed where the hot steel
billets in perfect shape then cools down so that it is
into shape that they want.  If any deformity comes while
cooling when it is shifted from one place to another, it
is then sent through the last section, which is the
straightener, which straightens any deformity in the
billet.
Now, going to the fourth area, this area has layer
forming and commercial cutting.  This area has layer
forming and commercial cutting, which is essentially
after the billet is in the shape that we want it to be,
it will be put into layers and cut into commercial
lengths.
And now that everything is in place, going to the
last area, which is the fifth area, the stacker machine
would stack all the products in bundles and it would
then be strapped together so that it doesn't fall out,
and it then goes into storage from where it is
despatched to the customer or the market, so as to say.
Now, to put all of this into a video format and to
bring a clear picture to the honourable tribunal about
how it works, we'll just display a video.  Next slide,
please.
If we can just play this.
(Video played)
This is the charging area where the raw steel has
come in, and now this steel is being sent to the heating
furnace which, as I outlined, was SAIL's scope of work.
After it is heated for two hours, it is now coming
out of the reheating furnace and now it will go through
high pressure of water right here, this is the water
descaler, to remove any impurities.  Now going through
the roughing mill where the initial shape of the billet
comes out to be, and then here is where the end of the
billet are cut off, which are not in perfect shape, and
it goes into the crop shear bucket, which is like
a collecting dustbin, and then it suppose into the
finishing train where the entire shape is then perfected
through 10 stands.
Now, after all of this is done, this is commercial
lengths that are being cut of the billet.  It can be the
short or long, as we discussed.
Now it comes onto the exit table from where it is
transported to the cooling bed.
This is the cooling bed.  The hot billet will now
slide on to the cooling bed and it will lie there till
the time it becomes cool, and if there is any deformity
slightly here or there, then it will go through the
straightening machine where it will then become
straightened and the exact shape that the customer
wanted.
This is the straightening machine.
Then this comes out and then they will be stacking
in -- strapping of all the bundles as per the market
requirement.
If I may point out to my honourable tribunal that
this video is of the very plant that the dispute is
ongoing.  This is MSM Durgapur Steel Plant.
So this is stacking of the billets together and
bundle formation.
This is it.  Thank you so much.
Opening submissions by MR MARKANDA (continued)
MR MARKANDA:  We just introduce my Lords to a few technical
terminologies because these will be used repeatedly in
the submissions by both the parties, by all the parties
in fact.
So my Lords have seen that this is the entire
process, and my Lords have also seen that some part of
it is in the scope of respondent number 1, some for the
claimant, so this was divided amongst all the parties,
area 1, area 2, area 3, area 4 and area 5.
Now, my Lords, in this particular case, payment
terms are also decided amongst the parties and mentioned
in the contract document bundle {E7-35}, which is
appendix 3 of the contract.
So my Lords, kindly see "Terms of Payment".
My Lords, from clauses 2.1.1 to clauses 2.1.7 are the
various stages for making payments.  It's a stage-wise
payment system.
If my Lords will kindly see that first is 2.1.1 is:
"5 per cent ... of the total contract price
specified in Appendix-1 excluding taxes, duties [so and
so] shall be released on submission of following
drawings/documents/data and approval of general layout
drawing of the Shop."
The drawings they have been given, so when these are
done, I get 5 per cent payment.  Next page, please.
"5 per cent ... of the total contract price
specified in Appendix-1 excluding taxes, duties (except
service tax) and training charges shall be released on
the approval of basic engineering drawings under Clause
no. 2.1.1 of Appendix-3 and on placement of orders for
following equipments/items and submission of un-priced
copies of the purchase orders/internal orders of the
same ..."
In short, what it says is the first 5 per cent is on
submission of drawings, the next 5 per cent is on the
approval of the drawings as well as the placement of
orders, and by way of proof you have to give them the
purchase orders.
This is the second stage.
Now we come to 2.1.3:
"Seventy Seven and a half percent ... of the
Contract Price specified in the Appendix-1, excluding
taxes, duties (except service tax) and training charges
shall be released towards progress payments and 100%cent
of the taxes and duties on submission of documentary
evidence along with release of progress payment of 77.5%
as per Sub-Clause 2.3."
My Lords, 77.5 per cent was to be released
progressively on the performing of certain duties, so
this was worked out with the mutual consent of the
parties.
Then, my Lords, 2.1.4:
"Two and a half percent ... of the Contract Price
excluding taxes, duties, Service Tax & Education Cess
and training charges specified in the Appendix-1, shall
be released upon issue of Preliminary Acceptance
Certificate (PAC)."
So, my Lords, up to this point, 90 per cent payment
is made.  Up to the PAC, 90 per cent payment is made.
Now we come to 2.1.5:
"Two and a half percent ... of the Contract Price
excluding taxes, duties, Service Tax & Education Cess
and training charges specified in the Appendix-1, shall
be released upon issue of the Commissioning
Certificate."
So after that PAC, the next stage is commissioning
certificate, and 2.5 per cent payment after the
commissioning certificate is given.
Then 2.1.6:
"Five percent ... of the Contract Price ... shall be
released after establishment of Performance Guarantee
parameters ..."
That is the next 5 per cent.  But my Lords will
kindly recall that the date of completion will be the
date of the commissioning certificate.  So as of the
date of completion, 92.5 per cent payment has to be
released.  The balance 7.5 per cent would be after
completion of the work, but number 1, performance
guarantee parameters are established, 5 per cent, and
lastly, 2.1.7:
"Two and a half percent ... of the Contract Price
... shall be released upon issue of the Final Acceptance
Certificate ..."
That is the final payment, so this makes up a total
of 100 per cent.
Now, my Lords, in the present case, we have reached
only up to 2.1.4 which is 90 per cent payment upon PAC,
so the first four stages have been completed.
Now, this is where the dispute has arisen between
the parties.  This is the starting point of the dispute.
PAC, the preliminary acceptance certificate, was
issued to me on 17 March 2016, which is bundle .
My Lords can kindly have a look at the preliminary
acceptance certificate.  This is dated 17 March 2016.
Second page, please.
So the PAC is on the record of the honourable
tribunal.  My Lords, I'll just read for the kind
presentation of the honourable tribunal.  My Lords will
kindly note down the date, this is 17 March 2016, and it
says:
"Pursuant to Clause 24 (Preliminary Acceptance) of
General Conditions of Contract entered into between
[yourself] and the Durgapur Steel Plant, Steel Authority
of India Limited dated 11.05.10 relating to the Medium
Structural Mill, we hereby notify you that the erection,
testing & trial runs of the individual unit of the
following part(s) of the Facilities were completed
successfully on the date specified below.  The
facilities are fit for start-up and commissioning.
However, you shall liquidate all the outstanding defects
and/or deficiencies and complete the balance items
listed in the attachment hereto, as soon as possible, so
that the Facilities are fully in accordance with the
requirements of the Contract and commissioning
activities of the Facilities can be started.  Further,
you shall be fully responsible for care and custody of
the Facilities and the risk of loss thereof till the
issue of commissioning certificate in terms of the
Contract.
1.  Description of the Facilities or part thereof:
Medium Structural Mill.
2.  Date of completion of Trial Runs: 15.03.16.
This letter does not relieve you of your obligation
to complete the execution, commissioning, establishment
of performance guarantee parameters of the Facilities in
accordance with the Contract nor of your obligations
during the Defects Liability Period."
My Lord, this is the preliminary acceptance
certificate issued to me by respondent number 1.
My Lord, the next stage is the stage of
commissioning.
Now, there is a very important fact which is to be
brought to the notice of the honourable tribunal, and
the fact is that clause 24 of the general conditions of
contract deals with the preliminary acceptance
certificate and the conditions attached thereto.
I invite the kind attention of the honourable tribunal
to bundle {E7-120}. 24.1 on the screen:
"On completion of the erection of the Facilities by
the Contractor, trial runs for individual
equipment/units shall be conducted by the Contractor to
prove that the Facilities have been supplied and erected
as per Contract and after erection, Facilities are fit
for start up and commissioning."
This is 24.1 and this is very words find mentioned
in the PAC also, which I have just read out to my Lords.
The words "facilities are fit for start up and
commissioning", the words are there as well.
My Lords may kindly come to the fourth subparagraph
of this clause, 24.1:
"On successful completion by the Contractor of trial
runs and liquidation of the defects and/or deficiencies,
indicated/listed by the Employer to the Contractor
during trial runs (except minor defects and/or
deficiencies which in the opinion of the Employer will
not affect the operation, safety & commissioning of the
Facilities), the Contractor shall so notify the Employer
in writing for conducting integrated trial runs."
Now, my Lords, I stop here for a moment.  Something
very important turns upon this paragraph of 24.1.  It
says "liquidation of the defects and/or deficiencies,
indicated by the Employer to the Contractor during trial
runs".
In the present case, my Lords, during trial runs,
not even a single defect was pointed out to me, during
trial runs.  At least there's nothing on the record of
this honourable tribunal that during trial runs this was
done.
I state it now that it was along with the PAC that
they gave me a punch list.  That is on 17 March 2016
they gave me the punch list, but during the trial runs
there is no defect list.
My Lords, I come to 24.2.  Before I go to 24.2, one
important aspect is it was only when I have liquidated
those defects that the next stage, which is 24.2, will
come, and that is:
"On receipt of the notice from the Contractor for
conducting integrated trial runs, the Employer, if
required, shall deploy the necessary operating and
maintenance personnel, raw materials, utility & services
as per Clause 7 hereof.  However, the Contractor shall
supply commissioning spares ..."
So, my Lords, 24.2 speaks of whether the respondent
wants to deploy its personnel or not.  It's their
choice.  We have no objection to that.
"As mutually agreed between the Contractor and the
Employer after operating maintenance personnel have been
deployed by the Employer and raw materials, utilities &
services have been provided by the Employer in
accordance with Sub-Clause 24.2 hereof, the Contractor
shall conduct Pre-Commissioning including integrated
trial runs of the Facilities, in preparation for
Commissioning."
So I have to then commence the integrated trial
runs.
Now my Lords may kindly come to 24.4 straightaway on
the next page:
"As soon as all the works in respect of integrated
Pre-Commissioning are completed and the Facilities are
ready for Commissioning, the Contractor shalt so notify
the Engineer in writing."
"The Engineer shall, within fourteen ... days after
receipt of the Contractor's notice under Sub-Clause 24.4
hereof ..."
Now, my Lords, two options:
"... either issue a Preliminary Acceptance
Certificate ... stating that the Facilities are fit for
start-up and commissioning, as at the date of the
Contractor's notice under Sub-Clause 24.4 hereof, or
notify the Contractor in writing of any defects and/or
deficiencies."
My Lords, after my notice they have two choices.
One, issue the PAC.  Two, notify the defects.  In the
present case, what has happened is they have issued me
the PAC on 17 March 2016 which I have shown to my Lords,
which in bundle .
My Lords, the next subparagraph is in relation to
the defects which have been mentioned in clause 24.5.
The next paragraph says:
"If the Engineer notifies the Contractor of any
defects and/or deficiencies, the Contractor shall then
correct such defects and/or deficiencies and shall
repeat the procedure described in Sub-Clause 24.4
hereof."
My Lords, it says I will rectify the defects,
re-notify the employer to conduct the tests, but this is
in respect of the defects, which are pointed out.
Instead of giving me a PAC, those defects are pointed
out.
But in the present case, my Lords, the PAC has been
given so the list of defects appended to the PAC are new
defects.  They are not the defects which are
contemplated under clause 24.
Next:
"If the Engineer is satisfied that the defects
and/or deficiencies, indicated/listed by the Employer to
the Contractor have been liquidated and the Facilities
are fit for start-up and commissioning, the Engineer
shall, within seven ... days after receipt of the
Contractor's repeated notice [this is important:
repeated notice], issue is Preliminary Acceptance
Certificate stating that the Facilities are fit for
start-up and commissioning, as at the date of the
Contractor's repeated notice."
Therefore, this further establishes my submission
that the defects, unless removed, no PAC will be given
to me.  If the defects are pointed out, I have to first
liquidate those defects, re-notify them by way of
a repeated notice, and then they will issue me the PAC,
if they're satisfied that the defects have been
liquidated.
Then the next subparagraph:
"If the Engineer is not so satisfied, then the
Employer shall notified the Contractor in writing of any
defects and/or deficiencies within seven ... days after
receipt of the Contractor's repeated notice, and the
above procedure shall be repeated."
So unless all the defects are liquidated to the
satisfaction of the employer, I will have to keep on
giving repeated notices after rectifying those defects.
Lastly, 24.6:
"As soon as possible, after issue of Preliminary
Acceptance Certificate, the Contractor shall complete
all outstanding defects and/or deficiencies so that the
Facilities are fully in accordance with the requirements
of the Contract, failing which the Employer will
undertake such completion and deduct the costs thereof
from any money owing to the Contractor."
Therefore, my Lords, this is the state after -- this
is not really applicable to the present case.
My Lords, admittedly, along with the PAC, there is
a defect list -- punch list as we put it.  A large
number of defects are mentioned there.  There's no
dispute on that account as well.
But my respectful submission before the honourable
tribunal is that those defects are of no consequence
whatsoever, because they were never pointed out to me
during the trial runs.  They had been done only along
with the PAC, which situation is not contemplated.
So this is an act which has been done over and above
the terms of clause 24.
Now, my Lords, second point.
Under clause 24, the respondent is to issue me
a preliminary acceptance certificate -- pure,
simple, clear.
Where is the provision in the contract for issuing
a conditional PAC or a PAC along with the list of
defects?  No such provision exists in the contract.
Therefore, what the respondent has done is they have
acted in a manner which is much beyond the terms of
the contract.
This, in my respectful submission, should not deter
or should not have deterred me or respondent number 1
for going to the next stage, which is commissioning.
In this case, what happens?  Unheard of anywhere in
the history of this country, in any steel mill, the
moment the PAC is issued to me, the next step is
commissioning, which has to be done by me, and then
they'll issue me a commissioning certificate.
